messageBody:
Hello Paige,

A very well put e-mail! Thanks for your comments.

My comments on "shortness" was only for refference
purposes. I think Qucikscript is fine just as it is
now.

If you look at the http://www.omniglot.com/index.htm
web page it shows many writing systems. I was just
noting that some use special markings to denote
inflections, shortness or longness in speaks.

Again thanks for you weel put e-mail
Chuck

--- "C. Paige Gabhart" <pgabhart@...> wrote:
> Chuck:
>
> I agree with you regarding letting accent come
> through in the spelling.
> I do not see that it is a big problem if people
> spell words according to
> their pronunciation of those words. The alternative
> would be to impose
> an external standard for spelling. In other words,
> one would have to
> convince people to accept and use a pronunciation
> other than their own
> to determine how words should be spelt. Of course,
> despite the alleged
> "good intentions" of the group attempting to impose
> the "standard,"
> those asked to spell with someone else's
> pronunciation will probably
> inevitably believe their own dialect is considered
> inferior to the
> "standard" as they are instructed not to use it. The
> result would
> probably be that they would resist using the new
> alphabet.
>
> The second and more serious problem is that if one
> has to learn an
> artificial standard, then that defeats, at least to
> some extent, the
> whole purpose of alphabet reform. I believe it is
> fair to say most of
> the people on the Shavian group have concluded that
> a "standard" is
> necessary although some believe a British version
> and an American
> version would probably be advantageous. This would
> reduce the level of
> phonicity (1 to 1 correspondence between speech and
> spelling) of QS.
>
> In my opinion, accepting this argument puts us back,
> at least to some
> extent, into the situation we are in now in which
> words are spelt in
> ways which the individual's pronunciation does not
> match. English
> speakers have been stuck with an alphabet that works
> so poorly for so
> long, that when you try to reorganize it, even the
> people interested in
> reform want to return to a system with less
> phonicity almost immediately
> by alleging it is "necessary."
>
> But what is necessary is communication. The only
> reason to be concerned
> whether there is a "standard" spelling is if it
> negatively affects
> communication. I do not believe it will prevent
> people from deciphering
> words written in QS since language is full of
> redundancies. Nor do I
> believe it will even slow a person's reading speed
> appreciably once they
> have attained QS fluency.
>
> For beginners using junior QS, we could develop a
> system to mark the
> vowel of the accented syllable. This might be useful
> initially.
>
> Your comment regarding "those who would want to note
> any shortness" was
> obscure to me. The "hot" vowel is short. The longer
> vowel in brit-speak
> "father" I seldom use. Why would there be a need to
> represent "shortness"?
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
